user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_named_thread_:
```c
int
MHD_create_named_thread_ (MHD_thread_handle_ID_ *handle_id,
                          const char *thread_name,
                          size_t stack_size,
                          MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_ start_routine,
                          void *arg)
{
#if defined(MHD_USE_THREAD_ATTR_SETNAME)
  int res;
  pthread_attr_t attr;
#if defined(MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_)
  pthread_t *const new_tid_ptr =
    MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_ (handle_id);
#else  /* ! MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_ */
  pthread_t new_tid;
  pthread_t *const new_tid_ptr = &new_tid;
#endif /* ! MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_ */

  res = pthread_attr_init (&attr);
  if (0 == res)
  {
#if defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_ATTR_SETNAME_NP_NETBSD)
    /* NetBSD uses 3 arguments: second argument is string in printf-like format,
     *                          third argument is single argument for printf;
     * OSF1 uses 3 arguments too, but last one always must be zero (NULL).
     * MHD doesn't use '%' in thread names, so both forms are used in same way.
     */
    res = pthread_attr_setname_np (&attr,
                                   thread_name,
                                   0);
#elif defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_ATTR_SETNAME_NP_IBMI)
    res = pthread_attr_setname_np (&attr,
                                   thread_name);
#else
#error No pthread_attr_setname_np() function.
#endif
    if ((res == 0) && (0 != stack_size) )
      res = pthread_attr_setstacksize (&attr,
                                       stack_size);
    if (0 == res)
      res = pthread_create (new_tid_ptr,
                            &attr,
                            start_routine,
                            arg);
    pthread_attr_destroy (&attr);
  }
  if (0 != res)
  {
    errno = res;
    MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_invalid_ (handle_id);
  }
#if ! defined(MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_)
  else
    MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_native_handle_ (handle_id, new_tid);
#endif /* ! MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_current_thread_ID_ */

  return ! res;
#else  /* ! MHD_USE_THREAD_ATTR_SETNAME */
  struct MHD_named_helper_param_ *param;

  if (NULL == thread_name)
  {
    errno = EINVAL;
    return 0;
  }

  param = malloc (sizeof (struct MHD_named_helper_param_));
  if (NULL == param)
    return 0;

  param->start_routine = start_routine;
  param->arg = arg;
  param->name = thread_name;

  /* Set thread name in thread itself to avoid problems with
   * threads which terminated before name is set in other thread.
   */
  if (! MHD_create_thread_ (handle_id,
                            stack_size,
                            &named_thread_starter,
                            (void *) param))
  {
    int err_num;

    err_num = errno;
    free (param);
    errno = err_num;
    return 0;
  }

  return ! 0;
#endif /* ! MHD_USE_THREAD_ATTR_SETNAME */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#if defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_ATTR_SETNAME_NP_NETBSD)
    /* NetBSD uses 3 arguments: second argument is string in printf-like format,
     *                          third argument is single argument for printf;
     * OSF1 uses 3 arguments too, but last one always must be zero (NULL).
     * MHD doesn't use '%' in thread names, so both forms are used in same way.
     */
    res = pthread_attr_setname_np (&attr,
                                   thread_name,
                                   0);
#elif defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_ATTR_SETNAME_NP_IBMI)
    res = pthread_attr_setname_np (&attr,
                                   thread_name);
#else
#error No pthread_attr_setname_np() function.
#endif
explanation:
I flagged code regions controlled by preprocessor conditionals and the #error branch because, for a given project configuration, one side of each conditional will be permanently excluded from the build and thus effectively unreachable in the project. Specifically: the top-level MHD_USE_THREAD_ATTR_SETNAME / else branches are mutually exclusive; the nested MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_ branches define distinct alternatives (one defines new_tid, the other does not); the HAVE_PTHREAD_ATTR_SETNAME_NP_* alternatives (including the #error) are mutually exclusive and the #error path can cause a compile-time failure if none is defined; and the conditional else paired with if (0 != res) is wrapped by a preprocessor conditional that may remove the else, changing reachability. These preprocessor-conditioned fragments should be investigated in the context of the project macro definitions to ensure no code is permanently unreachable.

I did not mark ordinary runtime conditionals (for example: if (0 == res), if (NULL == param), the error-handling returns, the pthread calls, and the return !res / return !0 statements) because they are dependent on runtime data and are not intrinsically unreachable. I also did not flag comments or single-line statements that are clearly reachable in at least one configuration. If project-wide macro definitions make some of the above runtime conditionals constant (always true/false) that would be a separate issue to verify at project level, but based on the translation unit alone these runtime branches cannot be proven unreachable and thus were not reported.
